From Wiktionary, the free dictionary

English

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From sign +‎ -er.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • Audio (US):(file)
  • Rhymes: -aɪnə(ɹ)

Noun

[edit]

signer (plural signers)

  1. One who signs.
    Hypernym: person
    1. One who signs their name (applies their signature to something).
      Synonym: signatory
      John Hancock is a famous signer of the Declaration of Independence.
    2. One who uses sign language.
      Hyponym: native signer
      Among the hundreds of signers at the conference, most were native signers.
      Coordinate terms: speaker, writer, scribe

Derived terms

[edit]
  • robo-signer

Translations

[edit]
one who signs
  • Catalan: signant (ca) m or f, signatari m, firmant (ca) m or f
  • Finnish: allekirjoittaja (fi)
  • Galician: asinante (gl) m or f, signatario (gl) m
  • Hungarian: aláíró (hu)
  • Portuguese: signatário (pt) m
  • Spanish: firmante (es) m or f, signatario (es) m
one who uses sign language
  • Finnish: viittomakielen käyttäjä
  • Hungarian: jelelő
  • Lithuanian: gestakal̃bis m, gestakal̃bė f
  • Portuguese: sinalizador (pt) m
  • Spanish: señante m,

Anagrams

[edit]
  • Greins, Negris, Singer, nigres, re-nigs, re-sign, reigns, renigs, resign, resing, ringes, singer

French

[edit]

Etymology

[edit]

From a modification, based on signe, of Old French seignier, itself from Latin signāre.

Pronunciation

[edit]
  • IPA(key): /si.ɲe/
  • Audio:(file)
  • Audio (France (Vosges)):(file)
  • Audio (France (Somain)):(file)

Verb

[edit]

signer

  1. (transitive) to sign (put a signature on)
  2. to sign (communicate using sign language)
  3. (reflexive, Christianity) to cross oneself (make the sign of the cross)

2 In less formal writing or speech, these tenses may be found to have been replaced in the following way:

past anterior → pluperfect
imperfect subjunctive → present subjunctive
pluperfect subjunctive → past subjunctive

(Christopher Kendris [1995], Master the Basics: French, pp. 77, 78, 79, 81).

Latin

[edit]

Verb

[edit]

signer

  1. first-person singular present passive subjunctive of signō

Norwegian Bokmål

[edit]

Verb

[edit]

signer

  1. imperative of signere

Old French

[edit]

Alternative forms

[edit]
  • ceiner
  • sainer
  • sainier
  • seigner
  • seignier
  • seiner
  • seingner
  • seinner
  • sener

Etymology

[edit]

First known attestation circa 1230.[1] Borrowed (in this form) from Latin signō, signāre. Cf. the inherited form seignier.

Verb

[edit]

signer

  1. to sign (put one's signature or one's seal on a document, etc.)

Conjugation

[edit]

This verb conjugates as a first-group verb ending in -er. The forms that would normally end in *-ign, *-igns, *-ignt are modified to ing, inz, int. Old French conjugation varies significantly by date and by region. The following conjugation should be treated as a guide.

    Conjugation of signer (see also Appendix:Old French verbs)
simple compound
infinitive signer avoir signé
gerund en signant gerund of avoir + past participle
present participle signant
past participle signé
person singular plural
first second third first second third
indicative jo tu il nos vos il

tenses 		present sing signes signe signons signez signent
imperfect signoie, signeie, signoe, signeve signoies, signeies, signoes, signeves signoit, signeit, signot, signeve signiiens, signiens signiiez, signiez signoient, signeient, signoent, signevent
preterite signai signas signa signames signastes signerent
